column5:
Johnson & Johnson Split Consumer Pharmaceutical, Medical-Device Businesses, Creating Companies; Consumer businessâ€”home Band-Aid Tylenolâ€”will 24 months
The world's largest health-products company by sales will separate its high-margin but less predictable prescription-drug and medical-device businesses from its storied but slower-growing consumer group, creating two publicly traded companies.
"The best path forward to ensure sustainable growth over the long term and better meet patient and consumer demands is to have our consumer business operate as a separate healthcare company," Mr. Gorsky said in an interview.
What form the separation will take, what the new consumer-oriented company will be called and who will lead it are yet to be worked out, Mr. Gorsky said, though he said J&J planned to structure the transaction to be tax-free.
It is likely J&J would spin out its consumer unit and hold a stock offering, but no decision has been made, Mr. Gorsky said.
The trimmer J&J, which will keep the name, will still stand as the world's largest health-products company, with yearly sales approaching $80 billion, Chief Financial Officer Joseph Wolk said.
The consumer division has generally contributed the smallest profit of J&J's three main divisions, less than the contribution from prescription-drug sales or medical-device sales.
While J&J's pharmaceutical sales have surged in recent years, the consumer business was recovering from a series of recalls, including of millions of bottles of Tylenol and other over-the-counter medicines in 2009 and 2010, because of manufacturing problems.
At times in the mid-2000s, J&J's consumer business was posting the strongest sales growth of the three main units.
The unit was bolstered in 2006, when J&J bought Pfizer Inc.'s consumer business, including Listerine, for $16.6 billion.
For J&J, the Covid-19 pandemic has accelerated the divergent potential of its pharmaceutical and consumer businesses and intensified discussions among board members about separating them, Mr. Gorsky said.
Rockoff at Jonathan.Rockoff@wsj.com and Peter Loftus at peter.loftus@wsj.com Johnson & Johnson to Split Consumer From Pharmaceutical, Medical-Device Businesses, Creating Two Companies
column6: Johnson & Johnson plans to break up into two companies, splitting off the $15-billion-a-year division that sells Band-Aid bandages, Tylenol medicines and Johnson's Baby Powder in a shift indicating just how much healthcare has changed since the company helped pioneer the industry. The world's largest health-products company by sales will separate its high-margin but less predictable prescription-drug and medical-device businesses from its storied but slower-growing consumer group, creating two publicly traded companies. J&J will shed its consumer division in 18 to 24 months, Chief Executive Alex Gorsky said. J&J decided to make the change, he said, because the businesses, their customers and markets have diverged so much in recent years, including during the pandemic. Lawsuits that alleged use of Johnson's Baby Powder caused cancer didn't play a role, he said. "The best path forward to ensure sustainable growth over the long term and better meet patient and consumer demands is to have our consumer business operate as a separate healthcare company," Mr. Gorsky said in an interview. What form the separation will take, what the new consumer-oriented company will be called and who will lead it are yet to be worked out, Mr. Gorsky said, though he said J&J planned to structure the transaction to be tax-free. It is likely J&J would spin out its consumer unit and hold a stock offering, but no decision has been made, Mr. Gorsky said. The decision comes after rivals including Pfizer Inc. and Merck & Co. decided to hive off their consumer businesses and double down on faster-growing pharmaceuticals. This week, General Electric Co. said it would break into three public companies, another example of large, diversified companies reassessing their structures and seeking to find stronger growth by separating into smaller units focused on their core competencies. The trimmer J&J, which will keep the name, will still stand as the world's largest health-products company, with yearly sales approaching $80 billion, Chief Financial Officer Joseph Wolk said. The consumer company will be among the industry's largest, after competitors such as Procter & Gamble Co., NestlÃ© SA and L'OrÃ©al SA. J&J shares rose more than 1% Friday on the news. "Given that there is not much synergy between the consumer business and the other JNJ segments, this initiative makes sense," Wells Fargo analyst Larry Biegelsen said in a note to investors. The separation will kick off the biggest change in direction in J&J's 135-year history. Disposable diapers, indigestion tablets and cough remedies powered J&J during its first century, then provided the diversification that helped the company ride out the ups and downs of its riskier but higher-reward pharmaceuticals and medical-devices businesses. The decision to pull all Tylenol from store shelves during a safety scare in 1982 endeared J&J to many consumers. Today, the consumer-health business sells well-known brandsâ€”from Neutrogena skin moisturizers to Zyrtec allergy pillsâ€”that include four that ring up $1 billion in sales each year and 20 generating more than $150 million in annual sales. The unit is also home to J&J's namesake brand, Johnson's Baby. The division has grown apart from J&J's other units in recent years. Sales are growing more slowly than at the other businesses, and have lower margins. It depends on recognition of name brands such as Aveeno, Neutrogena and Listerine, which are marketed directly to consumers. Endorsements by celebrities and sales via e-commerce websites increasingly play the decisive role in commercial success. "People are now looking to folks that they idolize and say, 'If that product works for them, it's going to work for me, too,' " Mr. Wolk said in an interview. Prescription drugs and medical devices require different corporate skill sets. They undergo tight regulatory scrutiny before they can go on sale and are monitored closely afterward. Their commercial success depends heavily on the choices of doctors and hospitals as well as payment by health insurers. Prescription drugs and devices also spring from more-advanced research than consumer goods. The next-generation drugs and devices are requiring yearslong and heavy investments in research into human genetics and molecular biology, artificial intelligence and optical recognition. J&J's pharmaceuticals business, which sells therapies for diseases ranging from prostate cancer to pulmonary arterial hypertension, developed one of only three Covid-19 vaccines authorized in the U.S. Wall Street also has different expectations for the businesses. The consumer unit's sales rose 1.1% to $15 billion last year, after growth of 0.3% the previous year. In contrast, J&J's pharmaceutical unit posted sales growth of 8% last year and 3.6% the previous year. The consumer division has generally contributed the smallest profit of J&J's three main divisions, less than the contribution from prescription-drug sales or medical-device sales. While J&J's pharmaceutical sales have surged in recent years, the consumer business was recovering from a series of recalls, including of millions of bottles of Tylenol and other over-the-counter medicines in 2009 and 2010, because of manufacturing problems. In addition, it has faced lawsuits alleging talc-containing Johnson's Baby Powder caused cancer or mesothelioma. J&J has said its talc-containing baby powder is safe, doesn't contain asbestos and doesn't cause cancer. It created a subsidiary and placed it in bankruptcy to resolve the talc claims quickly. Mr. Gorsky said J&J has corrected the manufacturing issues that led to recalls. It upgraded the plant in Fort Washington, Pa., that makes Tylenol. In July, the Food and Drug Administration lifted a consent decree that had put three consumer-division manufacturing plants under scrutiny. One risk of splitting off the consumer division is that J&J will have less of a buffer to smooth out sales and profit if one of the remaining divisions stumbles or encounters a market downturn. J&J has long touted its diversified business model as a strength. At various points, weakness in one unit would be offset by strong sales in another. At times in the mid-2000s, J&J's consumer business was posting the strongest sales growth of the three main units. The unit was bolstered in 2006, when J&J bought Pfizer Inc.'s consumer business, including Listerine, for $16.6 billion. A stand-alone consumer business, however, won't be able to draw on a well-endowed parent while it competes with bigger rivals. The new company will be in a better position standing alone to allocate resources and make other decisions, said Joaquin Duato, vice chairman of J&J's executive committee, who will become chief executive in January and eventually lead the pharmaceutical and medical-device company. The leaner J&J, he said, will remain diversified by providing products for a range of diseases and based on various technologies, from cellular therapy to robotic-assisted surgery. The remaining J&J, he added, will intensify efforts to create products that combine medical devices with drugs, such as one in development that identifies lung tumors and then targets them with a cancer therapy. Another experimental product aims to treat bladder-cancer patients using a device that delivers a drug. SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS What does Johnson & Johnson's split mean for the future of the company? Join the conversation below. The split, Mr. Duato said in an interview, "is going to create two strong companies with fit-for-purpose models for the changing trajectory of health." Rival drugmakers have also been shedding units selling cough pills, daily vitamins and skin lotions in recent years. In 2019, Pfizer and GlaxoSmithKline combined their over-the-counter businesses into a joint venture, GSK Consumer Healthcare, which sells pain medicine Advil. Merck sold its consumer business, which makes Coppertone sunscreen, to Bayer AG for $14.2 billion in 2014. For J&J, the Covid-19 pandemic has accelerated the divergent potential of its pharmaceutical and consumer businesses and intensified discussions among board members about separating them, Mr. Gorsky said. Write to Jonathan D. Rockoff at Jonathan.Rockoff@wsj.com and Peter Loftus at peter.loftus@wsj.com Johnson & Johnson to Split Consumer From Pharmaceutical, Medical-Device Businesses, Creating Two Companies

Citing Safety Concerns, F.D.A. Limits J.&J. Covid Vaccine
WASHINGTON â€?In yet another setback for Johnson & Johnsonâ€™s coronavirus vaccine, the Food and Drug Administration on Thursday limited its use to adults who cannot or refuse to get the Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna vaccines, citing safety concerns.
The F.D.A. said that weighing the risks of Johnson & Johnsonâ€™s vaccine against the benefits, it had decided to limit its use to adults who cannot access Pfizerâ€™s or Modernaâ€™s vaccines, or for whom those shots are not â€œclinically appropriate.â€?One example would be people who experienced an extreme allergic reaction to the other two vaccines, the agency said.
It said the vaccine could also be given to adults who â€œwould otherwise not receive a Covid-19 vaccine.â€?Johnson & Johnson was eclipsed long ago by Pfizer and Moderna in the nationâ€™s vaccination campaign; federal officials have said the mRNA vaccines produced by those companies are both safer and more effective.
In its announcement, the F.D.A. cited more than six cases and close to one death attributed to the blood-clotting disorder for every two million shots of Johnson & Johnson vaccine administered in the United States.
column6:
The agency said the move reflected an updated analysis of the risk of a rare but serious blood-clotting condition in people who get the vaccine. WASHINGTON â€?In yet another setback for Johnson & Johnsonâ€™s coronavirus vaccine, the Food and Drug Administration on Thursday limited its use to adults who cannot or refuse to get the Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna vaccines, citing safety concerns. The agency said 60 cases of a rare but serious blood-clotting disorder have been identified, including nine deaths, out of about 18 million doses administered. The action comes about five months after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommended Modernaâ€™s and Pfizerâ€™s vaccines over Johnson & Johnsonâ€™s for booster shots. The F.D.A. said that weighing the risks of Johnson & Johnsonâ€™s vaccine against the benefits, it had decided to limit its use to adults who cannot access Pfizerâ€™s or Modernaâ€™s vaccines, or for whom those shots are not â€œclinically appropriate.â€?One example would be people who experienced an extreme allergic reaction to the other two vaccines, the agency said. It said the vaccine could also be given to adults who â€œwould otherwise not receive a Covid-19 vaccine.â€?Johnson & Johnson was eclipsed long ago by Pfizer and Moderna in the nationâ€™s vaccination campaign; federal officials have said the mRNA vaccines produced by those companies are both safer and more effective. In a statement, Johnson & Johnson said the F.D.A.â€™s action reflected the already-known risk of the side effect, not new data on the rate at which it occurs. But in a sign of the firmâ€™s own flagging interest in its vaccine, it has stopped providing sales outlooks for the shot to investors. Reports that the vaccine can trigger a condition known as thrombosis with thrombocytopenia syndrome have bedeviled it from early on. In April 2021, not long after it was approved for emergency use, federal authorities paused distribution of the vaccine for a safety evaluation. Regulators lifted the pause 10 days later but added a warning to instructions for its use. Then, in December, the C.D.C. recommended that adults seeking a booster shot choose Moderna or Pfizer instead of Johnson & Johnson, citing more benefits and lower risks. Coupled with a host of manufacturing troubles in the United States, some experts said, the agencyâ€™s judgment illustrated that the federal government had all but written off Johnson & Johnsonâ€™s vaccine. According to the F.D.A. announcement on Thursday, federal authorities now have 60 reports of the blood-clotting disorder â€?or four times as many as were reported when last yearâ€™s pause in distribution was lifted. In the interim, the number of Johnson & Johnson doses administered has slightly more than doubled, while the number of Pfizer and Moderna recipients has skyrocketed. The number of deaths attributed to the disorder triggered by the Johnson & Johnsonâ€™s vaccine does not appear to have risen much, if at all. But there have been far fewer, if any, suspected deaths due to side effects from the mRNA vaccines, federal health officials have said. In its announcement, the F.D.A. cited more than six cases and close to one death attributed to the blood-clotting disorder for every two million shots of Johnson & Johnson vaccine administered in the United States. About 17 million Americans have now gotten one dose of Johnson & Johnsonâ€™s vaccine, and another 1.5 million have gotten a booster dose, according to the C.D.C.â€™s data. By comparison, more than 200 million Americans have gotten at least two doses of either Modernaâ€™s or Pfizerâ€™s vaccine. Trying to cast the tight new restrictions in a positive light, Johnson & Johnson said: â€œData continue to support a favorable benefit-risk profile for the Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine in adults, when compared with no vaccine.â€?
Johnson & Johnson,JNJ,2022-07-12,products (health and environmental issues)

column19:
Johnson & Johnson Trims Full-Year Guidance Stronger Dollar; Healthcare-products company posts higher quarterly sales Covid-19 vaccine
Johnson & Johnson reported a profit decline for the latest quarter and cut its full-year sales and profit guidance, as a stronger U.S. dollar, macroeconomic pressures and the Covid-19 pandemic hit results of the healthcare-products company.
The New Brunswick, N.J.-based company, which makes Tylenol and Band-Aid, said Tuesday inflation has contributed to an increase in its costs for items including raw materials and transportation, which cut into its gross profit margins for the second quarter.
Tight Covid-19 pandemic restrictions in China reduced hospital procedures that used J&J medical devices, which curbed overall sales growth for the device division, Mr. Wolk said.
J&J's new chief executive, Joaquin Duato, said Tuesday the company continues to pursue mergers and acquisitions, and that beefing up the medical-device unit is a top priority for deals.
In the same period a year earlier, the company's Covid-19 vaccine sales were $164 million.
In the second quarter, J&J posted overall sales of $24 billion, compared with $23.3 billion a year earlier.

column23: Johnson & Johnson reported a profit decline for the latest quarter and cut its full-year sales and profit guidance, as a stronger U.S. dollar, macroeconomic pressures and the Covid-19 pandemic hit results of the healthcare-products company. The New Brunswick, N.J.-based company, which makes Tylenol and Band-Aid, said Tuesday inflation has contributed to an increase in its costs for items including raw materials and transportation, which cut into its gross profit margins for the second quarter. As a result, J&J is being more selective in its spending including hiring new employees, Chief Financial Officer Joseph Wolk said. "It's forcing us to probably be a little bit more discretionary in terms of investments we're able to make," he said. He added that J&J will give priority to research and development, however, for which spending rose 9.1% in the second quarter. The company now sees full-year sales up between 2.1% and 3.1%, down from a prior guidance of 3.8% to 4.8%. J&J now expects adjusted earnings for the year to grow between 2.1% and 3.1%, down from a prior forecast of 3.6% to 5.6%. Johnson & Johnson said on Tuesday the lowered view is largely due to the stronger dollar. The new guidance comes as the company reported a 3% increase in sales in its second quarter. Currency-exchange trends reduced overall sales growth by 5 percentage points. J&J's pharmaceutical unit, which makes the cancer drug Darzalex, continued to post strong growth, which helped offset declines in its medical-device and consumer-health units. Pharmaceutical sales rose 6.7%, versus a 1.1% decline in medical-device sales and a 1.3% decrease in consumer-health sales. Tight Covid-19 pandemic restrictions in China reduced hospital procedures that used J&J medical devices, which curbed overall sales growth for the device division, Mr. Wolk said. J&J's new chief executive, Joaquin Duato, said Tuesday the company continues to pursue mergers and acquisitions, and that beefing up the medical-device unit is a top priority for deals. J&J logged $544 million in revenue for its Covid-19 vaccine, with international buyers accounting for most of those sales. U.S. vaccine sales declined about 11.5%. In the same period a year earlier, the company's Covid-19 vaccine sales were $164 million. But the company also took a second-quarter charge of about $276 million for a reduction in research and manufacturing capacity for the shots, citing a global surplus of Covid-19 vaccine doses. The shot is one of four vaccines for Covid-19authorized or approved in the U.S., with Novavax Inc.'s vaccine most recently winning authorization. But use of the J&J shot in the U.S. has lagged behind that of vaccines developed by rival manufacturers Moderna Inc. and Pfizer Inc. U.S. health regulators briefly paused the use of the J&J vaccine in April of last year as they investigated rare blood-clotting conditions. SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS What is your outlook for Johnson & Johnson's business? Join the conversation below. About 17.1 million Americans have been vaccinated with J&J's single-dose shot, a fraction of the number who have been immunized with shots made by Moderna and by Pfizer and BioNTech SE, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Those companies' booster shots have also seen far more use in the U.S. than J&J's. In the second quarter, J&J posted overall sales of $24 billion, compared with $23.3 billion a year earlier. Analysts surveyed by FactSet were expecting quarterly sales of $23.77 billion. Profit was $4.81 billion, or $1.80 a share, down from $6.28 billion, or $2.35 a share, a year earlier. Adjusted for one-time costs, J&J's per-share profit was $2.59. Wall Street analysts had been forecasting an adjusted profit of $2.54, according to FactSet. J&J reiterated its plan to separate its consumer-health business into a stand-alone company in 2023. The move will leave J&J with its pharmaceutical and medical-device units. Write to Peter Loftus at peter.loftus@wsj.com and Will Feuer at will.feuer@wsj.com Johnson & Johnson Trims Full-Year Guidance on Stronger Dollar

column4: misleading communication, products (health and environmental issues)
column5:
PepsiCo U.S. companies accused 'moralwashing' statements Russia; Companies accused making statements Russia 'look actions,' Moral Rating Agency
A host of companies has been accused of making statements about Russia that "look better than their actions," according to the Moral Rating Agency.
The agency pointed to a Reuters report last month that PepsiCo had stopped making Pepsi, 7Up and Mountain Dew in Russia nearly six months after the company said it would suspend sales and production in the country.
In the letter he announced the suspension of "the sale of Pepsi-Cola, and our global beverage brands in Russia, including 7Up and Mirinda." See: Kremlin could seize Russian assets of U.S. companies, warns Moral Rating Agency A spokesperson for PepsiCo referred MarketWatch to a recent statement from the company.
"All concentrates have subsequently been exhausted in Russia and production has ended." The Moral Rating Agency contends that PepsiCo used confusing wording in its statement released on March 8.
Regarding Johnson & Johnson, the Moral Rating Agency accuses the company of using "confusing wording," arguing that the company's initial statement on March 4 didn't disclose the status of its personal-care products, which it later suspended.
column6: A host of companies has been accused of making statements about Russia that "look better than their actions," according to the Moral Rating Agency. The Moral Rating Agencyhas published a list of companies, both in the U.S. and overseas, that it accuses of "moralwashing," or making confusing statements about their involvement with Russia. The 12 companies in "the communications hall of shame" include PepsiCo Inc. PEP, Johnson & Johnson JNJ, Chevron Corp. CVX, Procter & Gamble Co. PG, Dell Technologies Inc. DELL and Goldman Sachs Group Inc. GS. To compile its latest report, the Moral Rating Agency analyzed the announcements of 112 companies that were involved in Russia at the time of the Ukraine invasion on Feb. 24. The agency classified "communications failure" into four categories: "confusing wording," "wriggle-room wording," "red herring" statements, and not disclosing one or more Russian activities properly, which the researchers describe as "corporate amnesia." "The 12 worst offenders didn't just fail to exit Russia properly," said Moral Rating Agency founder Mark Dixon, in a statement. "They also frequently moralwashed their failures by saying one thing and doing another." See: Six months after Russia invaded Ukraine, Moral Rating Agency's 'Courage Index' analyzes companies' statements on Kremlin's aggression "Continuing to work with Russia is immoral, but moralwashing it is 'doubly immoral'," he added. PepsiCo is at the top of the Moral Rating Agency's list. Researchers accused the consumer giant of "confusing wording" on several points, "corporate amnesia" about its snack-production business in Russia and issuing a "red herring" statement. The agency pointed to a Reuters report last month that PepsiCo had stopped making Pepsi, 7Up and Mountain Dew in Russia nearly six months after the company said it would suspend sales and production in the country. Reuters reported that it had visited dozens of supermarkets, retailers and gyms in Moscow and other areas and found Pepsi cans and bottles printed with July and August production dates from factories in Russia. On March 8 PepsiCo published a letter sent by CEO Ramon Laguarta to employees via email. In the letter he announced the suspension of "the sale of Pepsi-Cola, and our global beverage brands in Russia, including 7Up and Mirinda." See: Kremlin could seize Russian assets of U.S. companies, warns Moral Rating Agency A spokesperson for PepsiCo referred MarketWatch to a recent statement from the company. "In line with the announcement we made in March 2022, we ceased the manufacture of relevant concentrates for Pepsi-Cola, Mirinda, 7Up and Mountain Dew in the Russian market and suspended capital investments, advertising and promotional activities in Russia," the company said. "All concentrates have subsequently been exhausted in Russia and production has ended." The Moral Rating Agency contends that PepsiCo used confusing wording in its statement released on March 8. "When using the word 'sale', the company's initial statement didn't specify that it was only suspending deliveries of concentrates, which the company only clarified when the continuing production and sales were exposed by Reuters," it said, in its research. The Moral Rating Agency accused Dell of "corporate amnesia" regarding its ownership of a development center in St. Petersburg. It was months before the center's closure was announced, according to the Agency. A spokesperson for Dell told MarketWatch that the company closed its offices and ceased all Russian operations in mid-August. "Back in February, we made the decision to not sell, service or support products in Russia, Belarus and the Donetsk and Luhansk regions of Ukraine, in addition to the already embargoed Crimea," the spokesperson added, in an emailed statement. Regarding Johnson & Johnson, the Moral Rating Agency accuses the company of using "confusing wording," arguing that the company's initial statement on March 4 didn't disclose the status of its personal-care products, which it later suspended. See: Despite plenty of talk, many U.S. companies have still not fully exited Russia: Moral Rating Agency A Johnson & Johnson spokesperson referred MarketWatch to a statementreleased by the company on March 29. At that time, Johnson & Johnson announced its decision to suspend the supply of personal-care products to Russia. Johnson & Johnson in early March suspended all advertising, enrollment in clinical trials and any additional investment in the country. "We will continue to support those most directly impacted and are committed to providing access to our essential medical products in the countries where we operate, in compliance with current international sanctions," it said, in the statement on March 4. Chevron, Procter & Gamble and Goldman Sachs had not yet responded to a request for comment for this story. PepsiCo and other U.S. companies accused of 'moralwashing' in statements about Russia

column4: animal mistreatment
column5:
Aerosol hair products tainted benzene store shelves
Valisure, an independent lab in New Haven, Conn., published a new analysis testing 148 batches of dry shampoo products from 34 different brands, and found that 70 percent contained benzene.
Butane is a petroleum-based propellant, and if it isn't refined well, there's a chance that the end product could contain traces of benzene, said Chris Cappa, a professor of environmental engineering at the University of California at Davis.
"Aerosol sprays appear to be one of the highest-risk categories for benzene contamination in consumer products," said David Light, the chief executive of Valisure, who also warned in May 2021 of benzene contamination in sunscreen products.
"We don't want to scare people into never using an aerosol can ever again, but it is a real risk." In a statement announcing its recall of various dry shampoo products in October, Unilever said the company confirmed the propellant "as the source" of the benzene contamination.
The news that many of the favorite products we spray on our bodies might contain a cancer-causing contaminant has left some consumers concerned, prompting conversations on social media and online searches about benzene.
Some experts say the concern with any amount of benzene in consumer products, like dry shampoo or deodorant, is that we're often spraying these cans in enclosed spaces like small bathrooms where there's not a lot of air flow and a higher possibility of someone inhaling the known carcinogen.
"Any additional exposure you have from consumer products is going to increase your risk." Contamination in the supply chain?Homer Swei, a senior vice president at the Environmental Working Group, a research and advocacy organization, said he believes the supply chain of propellants for these different companies must have been affected to lead to such a wide range of recalls.
"They all have different supply chains." The string of aerosol can recalls started after Valisure, the independent laboratory based in New Haven, Conn., published two separate studies detecting traces of benzene in dozens of different deodorant and sunscreen brands.
Other spray cans use a "bag-on-valve" technology that separates the propellant from the product inside the can, said Marisa Plescia, a cosmetic chemist based in Minneapolis.
Clues that a product may use an alternate technology such as the bag-on-valve system are claims that the product doesn't contain flammable ingredients or has a "continuous spray." Kelly Dobos, a cosmetic chemist and professor at the University of Cincinnati, said if companies decide to change aerosol technologies, it will take time to adjust formulations or develop new products with a different spraying system.
"While the levels of benzene found in the products from the Unilever recall are not expected to cause adverse health consequences, the best advice I can give to consumers who are concerned is to eliminate aerosol usage." Swei said he would also tell his friends to avoid using these aerosol products "until the industry can fix these problems in the supply chain." "While there's some uncertainty, it's not good for you," Swei said.
column6: Aerosolized beauty products are popular and convenient, allowing us to spray our hair, faces and bodies with fine mists of deodorant, sunscreen and dry shampoo. But in the past 18 months, several major consumer products companies, including Unilever, Procter & Gamble and Johnson & Johnson, have announced at least 10 recalls of well-known aerosol brands. The reason: The products contained elevated amounts of benzene, a chemical known to cause cancer and compromise our immune system. It's not clear how widespread the problem is, and the major companies involved have refused to answer questions or provide additional details. The affected aerosol products include some of the world's biggest brand names including certain lots of Neutrogena, Aveeno, Banana Boat and Coppertone sunscreens; Sure, Brut, Suave, Secret and Old Spice deodorants; Dove, Nexxus, Suave, TRESemmÃ© and Bed Head dry shampoos, and Tinactin and Odor Eaters foot sprays. In October, the news got worse. Valisure, an independent lab in New Haven, Conn., published a new analysis testing 148 batches of dry shampoo products from 34 different brands, and found that 70 percent contained benzene. The highest level of benzene detected was 340 parts per million in 10 seconds of spray. By comparison the Food and Drug Administration has said that the acceptable level of benzene in a drug is two parts per million. A problem with the propellantThe issue appears to be related mostly to butane-powered propellants that create pressure inside an aerosol can, which is what ultimately allows us to spray a fine mist of the product when we press the nozzle. Butane is a petroleum-based propellant, and if it isn't refined well, there's a chance that the end product could contain traces of benzene, said Chris Cappa, a professor of environmental engineering at the University of California at Davis. "Aerosol sprays appear to be one of the highest-risk categories for benzene contamination in consumer products," said David Light, the chief executive of Valisure, who also warned in May 2021 of benzene contamination in sunscreen products. "We don't want to scare people into never using an aerosol can ever again, but it is a real risk." In a statement announcing its recall of various dry shampoo products in October, Unilever said the company confirmed the propellant "as the source" of the benzene contamination. Johnson & Johnson also said the contamination was related to the propellant, and said it has adopted new practices "to prevent such an occurrence in the future," a spokesman said. A spokesperson for Procter & Gamble said the company has "nothing to share" about the recalls. The news that many of the favorite products we spray on our bodies might contain a cancer-causing contaminant has left some consumers concerned, prompting conversations on social media and online searches about benzene. When Kyla Moore, 22, who lives in Alberta, Canada, and works in customer relations, heard about the recall, she discovered her can of Dove coconut dry shampoo was on the list of potentially tainted products. She threw it in the trash a few days after Unilever's announcement, and said she doesn't plan to buy it again after switching to a new shampoo she likes better. The brands with the highest levels of benzene in the newest round of tests include Not Your Mother's, Sun Bum, Paul Mitchell, dp Hue and Sebastian, none of which have been recalled. In a statement, Not Your Mother's said the report "is inconsistent with the data provided by our suppliers and the rigorous ongoing testing to ensure the safety and integrity of our products. These tests show no traceable amounts of benzene." Trace amounts of benzene can add upBenzene is used to make plastics, detergents, dyes and pesticides. Breathing or otherwise absorbing benzene over time can lead to leukemia, anemia and other blood disorders, according to the FDA. Much of the research on the harmful effects of benzene focuses on occupational hazards. One study published in 1977 found workers in the U.S. rubber industry were at least five times more likely to develop leukemia. We can be exposed to benzene in many ways. Rubber collars were added to gas pump nozzles to protect us from the benzene in gas fumes. We inhale benzene when we smoke tobacco and expose our families to benzene through second hand smoke. In a study published earlier this month, researchers found benzene leaking from gas stoves in California. "Everyone is exposed to benzene," said Stephen M. Rappaport, a professor emeritus at the University of California, Berkeley School of Public Health. "It's just a question of how much." The World Health Organization has said "there's no safe level" of exposure to benzene in the air we breathe. Some experts say the concern with any amount of benzene in consumer products, like dry shampoo or deodorant, is that we're often spraying these cans in enclosed spaces like small bathrooms where there's not a lot of air flow and a higher possibility of someone inhaling the known carcinogen. Last week, Stella Krause, a 20-year-old undergraduate student at the University of Chicago, learned about the recall on Twitter. Instead of giving up her Dove dry shampoo, she started spraying it on her hair outside. Krause said she already thought breathing in dry shampoo spray wasn't good for her lungs. "For carcinogens, it's not like there's some safe level," said Deborah Bennett, a professor of public health at the University of California at Davis. "Any additional exposure you have from consumer products is going to increase your risk." Contamination in the supply chain?Homer Swei, a senior vice president at the Environmental Working Group, a research and advocacy organization, said he believes the supply chain of propellants for these different companies must have been affected to lead to such a wide range of recalls. Swei said the good news is "the process is working" and companies are trying to understand the cause. The bad news is there appears to be problems with more than one supplier. "It hit everybody, it seems, at the same time, which is very strange," said Swei, who worked at Johnson & Johnson for nearly twenty years. "They all have different supply chains." The string of aerosol can recalls started after Valisure, the independent laboratory based in New Haven, Conn., published two separate studies detecting traces of benzene in dozens of different deodorant and sunscreen brands. Alternatives to aerosolsThis isn't the first time questions have been raised over the propellant used in our spray cans. For years, aerosol cans were propelled by chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs). But in the 1970s, researchers found CFCs are partially responsible for destroying the Earth's ozone layer, and companies stopped using them and eventually switched to other aerosol technologies, including butane-based propellants. But not all spray cans rely on petroleum-based propellants. Cans of whipped cream are often powered by nitrous oxide. Other spray cans use a "bag-on-valve" technology that separates the propellant from the product inside the can, said Marisa Plescia, a cosmetic chemist based in Minneapolis. To find out if your product contains a butane-powered propellant, just check the label. The chemicals used in the propellant should be listed in the ingredients or inactive ingredients box. Look for any ingredients that end in "-ane," such as propane, butane and isobutane, Plescia said. Clues that a product may use an alternate technology such as the bag-on-valve system are claims that the product doesn't contain flammable ingredients or has a "continuous spray." Kelly Dobos, a cosmetic chemist and professor at the University of Cincinnati, said if companies decide to change aerosol technologies, it will take time to adjust formulations or develop new products with a different spraying system. "Product development timelines are often a year, two years or more to account for testing and proving shelf life stability," Dobos said. "While the levels of benzene found in the products from the Unilever recall are not expected to cause adverse health consequences, the best advice I can give to consumers who are concerned is to eliminate aerosol usage." Swei said he would also tell his friends to avoid using these aerosol products "until the industry can fix these problems in the supply chain." "While there's some uncertainty, it's not good for you," Swei said. "The lower the better for known carcinogens. But, what that level is? We still don't know."

Clues that a product may use an alternate technology such as the bag-on-valve system are claims that the product doesn't contain flammable ingredients or has a "continuous spray." Kelly Dobos, a cosmetic chemist and professor at the University of Cincinnati, said if companies decide to change aerosol technologies, it will take time to adjust formulations or develop new products with a different spraying system. "Product development timelines are often a year, two years or more to account for testing and proving shelf life stability," Dobos said. "While the levels of benzene found in the products from the Unilever recall are not expected to cause adverse health consequences, the best advice I can give to consumers who are concerned is to eliminate aerosol usage." Swei said he would also tell his friends to avoid using these aerosol products "until the industry can fix these problems in the supply chain." "While there's some uncertainty, it's not good for you," Swei said. "The lower the better for known carcinogens. But, what that level is? We still don't know."

column5:
Kristin Lemkau: J.P. Morgan's Plan Scale Wealth Management
JPMorgan Chase surprised many back in 2019 by tapping its chief marketing officer to lead a newly unified wealth management business.
But Kristin Lemkau says her career has always been guided by a piece of advice she received long ago: "If you want a bigger job, make your own job bigger." Speaking with Barron's Advisor from an office at a Chase bank branch near her home in Rye, N.Y., Lemkau explains how her revenue-focused marketing work prepared her to lead J.P. Morgan U.S. Wealth Management, which has 4,000 advisors and $630 billion of assets under management.
She makes the case that digital cross-selling can help double the number of bank customers who do business with the wealth management unit.
Where did you grow up and how did you get into the wealth management business?
I ended up at J.P. Morgan somewhat accidentally in 1998, at what they call heritage J.P. Morganâ€”pre-Chase merger, pre-Bank One mergerâ€”and I took the job because I wanted to walk to work.
I had been doing some work for Jamie (Dimon, CEO of JPMorgan Chase), and Gordon Smith (CEO of the Consumer & Community Banking unit), and Mary Erdoes (CEO of the Asset & Wealth Management division), in late summer 2019 in my old job as CMO, to figure out how to grow the business.
Do you think anyone in the wealth management ranks was unhappy you were chosen to run the business since you don't come from that world?
And in my old job I helped write the plan for how they would grow this businessâ€”and they said, "Well, OK, go do that." Walk us through the rebranding, announced in October , in which the brokerage, branch-based advisors, and digital investment platforms were brought under the new J.P. Morgan Wealth Management brand.
Even if they invest with us in a Chase branch, what gets them over the line is the J.P. Morgan products and the research, and the J.P. Morgan advisor.
So we knew we had Chase Wealth Management, You Invest, J.P. Morgan Securities, and we were probably punching below our weight with all of these different fragments.
You have not publicly announced growth targets, but clearly they're ambitiousâ€”Jamie Dimon said in 2018 that the bank could double its wealth management market share .
Right now we've got the No. 1 wealth management app, according to J.D. Power, we have the No. 1 primary bank, we have the No. 1 online banking mobile app, and we're the fastest growing in deposits.
Whether it's a branch-based advisor, a J.P. Morgan advisor, a self-directed or robo client, and then as you know we're building out our hybrid advice component under Boaz Lahovitsky, who we hired from Vanguard about six months ago.
If we have 40 million people on the app and they're on it every day, why would they ever want to go invest, particularly for the first time, with somebody else, if we make it super easy for them to invest with us?
In terms of growth targets, we can share that we're aiming to double the number of Chase deposit clients that invest with J.P. Morgan Wealth Management.
(She declined to provide a timeframe.â€”Eds.) J.P. Morgan Wealth Management recently announced plans to hire 300 Black and Latinx advisors by 2025.
I'd say we've done a good job over the past three years of increasing our diversity pipeline within the branch-based advisors, and that was super intentional.
The first thing we did was create something called the Advisor Development Program, where we hire and develop diverse advisors with no former financial services experience through a three-year training, development, and support program.
And as you probably read, we will double down on both of those things as well as increase our pipeline from HBCUs and try some other paths to get more people to consider a career as an advisor.
I think if you go on campus and ask people, or if I ask my nephew's friends what they want to do, they'll say investment banking or they'll say consulting or they want to go work in a tech company.
We also have an internal training program for experienced advisors called the Advisor Growth Program, that's a two-to-three-year deep-training program around goals-based planning, where they come out with an internal certification as well as the WMCP (Wealth Management Certified Professional) designation, issued by the American College of Financial Services.
Start getting more into not just growing the money, but what they'll do with the money, particularly now because I think what's important to people has changed.
Kristin Lemkau: J.P. Morgan's Plan to Scale Up Wealth Management
column6: JPMorgan Chase surprised many back in 2019 by tapping its chief marketing officer to lead a newly unified wealth management business. But Kristin Lemkau says her career has always been guided by a piece of advice she received long ago: "If you want a bigger job, make your own job bigger." Speaking with Barron's Advisor from an office at a Chase bank branch near her home in Rye, N.Y., Lemkau explains how her revenue-focused marketing work prepared her to lead J.P. Morgan U.S. Wealth Management, which has 4,000 advisors and $630 billion of assets under management. She makes the case that digital cross-selling can help double the number of bank customers who do business with the wealth management unit. And she explains why she doesn't shy away from weighing in on hot-button topics like racial justice and inequality on social media. Where did you grow up and how did you get into the wealth management business? I was born in Boston into a big Boston sports fan family. We moved to New Jersey when I was in fifth grade, but we went to Massachusetts every summer, so I still claim that I'm from New England. My father actually worked at Merrill Lynch for 25 years, but it wasn't anything that I ever thought I would get into. I majored in creative writing and thought I was going to, I don't know, change the world. I ended up at J.P. Morgan somewhat accidentally in 1998, at what they call heritage J.P. Morganâ€”pre-Chase merger, pre-Bank One mergerâ€”and I took the job because I wanted to walk to work. I figured I would work there for a few years, and 22 years later I'm now the CEO of what is potentially the biggest growth opportunity of the firm. What did your dad do at Merrill? He started out as a financial advisor. He ran different offices and then he ran the research department by the time he left. And then he worked at Prudential for I don't remember how long, maybe five or 10 years, and then he retired at Lord Abbett. He passed away seven and a half years ago but he would have been really proud. How did your transition from running marketing to running a business lineâ€”an unlikely trajectoryâ€”come about? Going from CMO to CEO was not impossible but certainly unorthodox. I had been doing some work for Jamie (Dimon, CEO of JPMorgan Chase), and Gordon Smith (CEO of the Consumer & Community Banking unit), and Mary Erdoes (CEO of the Asset & Wealth Management division), in late summer 2019 in my old job as CMO, to figure out how to grow the business. And during the course of that work I think I realized, and maybe they realized, that I could do this job. Do you think anyone in the wealth management ranks was unhappy you were chosen to run the business since you don't come from that world? I don't knowâ€”you'll have to ask them. Hopefully they're happy now. Why do you think they gave you the opportunity? Hopefully, it's because of the way I ran marketing. Your job as a marketer is to grow the business, full stop. It's not to win awards, it's not to go to conferences; it's to be accountable for growth. I always held the marketing team accountable first for clear, revenue-driving metrics. Even if that budget and those metrics were owned by the business, we had to be able to measure our contribution to all that. I was very performance-marketing driven, particularly about growing our affluent market share. I helped launch the Sapphire Card. I helped launch Sapphire Banking. So we were deeply involved in product development. And in my old job I helped write the plan for how they would grow this businessâ€”and they said, "Well, OK, go do that." Walk us through the rebranding, announced in October , in which the brokerage, branch-based advisors, and digital investment platforms were brought under the new J.P. Morgan Wealth Management brand. All of the research pointed to the fact that the J.P. Morgan brand is a critical asset for us. It's the reason people trust us, and it's the reason people want to invest with us. Even if they invest with us in a Chase branch, what gets them over the line is the J.P. Morgan products and the research, and the J.P. Morgan advisor. So we knew we had Chase Wealth Management, You Invest, J.P. Morgan Securities, and we were probably punching below our weight with all of these different fragments. And we said, the best thing we can do is align it all under J.P. Morgan and put a lot of marketing heft behind that. You have not publicly announced growth targets, but clearly they're ambitiousâ€”Jamie Dimon said in 2018 that the bank could double its wealth management market share . What are the growth levers? I think the big opportunity for us is to convert the embedded base. Right now we've got the No. 1 wealth management app, according to J.D. Power, we have the No. 1 primary bank, we have the No. 1 online banking mobile app, and we're the fastest growing in deposits. So for us the core to that strategy is converting clientsâ€”mostly the deposit clients but also the lending clientsâ€”into investment clients. Doing that both in the physical branch and on the app because, yes, we want to compete with Morgan Stanley and Merrill and all of the traditional players, but we also want to compete with Fidelity and Schwab and Robinhood, and we likely have better distribution than all of them except for BofA. How can you increase cross-selling? I'll just take the branch-based business. Relationship building with the deposit-based client inside the branch is highly effective. Over 90% of our referrals come from the banker in the branch, and it's a partnership that nobody else has been able to replicate. The next step is having that same kind of success in a digital platform. We have 40 million people on the app. How do I get all those people engaged in experience? Whether it's a branch-based advisor, a J.P. Morgan advisor, a self-directed or robo client, and then as you know we're building out our hybrid advice component under Boaz Lahovitsky, who we hired from Vanguard about six months ago. What I think became super clear to all of us is that we weren't optimizing the digital experience. If we have 40 million people on the app and they're on it every day, why would they ever want to go invest, particularly for the first time, with somebody else, if we make it super easy for them to invest with us? Can you quantify how much you're aiming to grow? In terms of growth targets, we can share that we're aiming to double the number of Chase deposit clients that invest with J.P. Morgan Wealth Management. (She declined to provide a timeframe.â€”Eds.) J.P. Morgan Wealth Management recently announced plans to hire 300 Black and Latinx advisors by 2025. Where do you think the industry's diversity problems stem from? The industry's got two problems. They don't have enough diversity in their advisor ranks and theyâ€”weâ€”don't have enough diversity in our clients. As far as the advisors, I can't speak to where the industry went sideways but it is startling when you see the consistent lack of progress. I'd say we've done a good job over the past three years of increasing our diversity pipeline within the branch-based advisors, and that was super intentional. But we still have a ways to go. Can you quantify that? Fifty-one percent of JPMorgan Chase & Co.'s U.S. employees are racially diverse, with 41% in midlevel manager positions, and 19% in senior or executive positions. Women represent 53% of the total workforce in the U.S., 42% are in middle-management positions, and 27% in senior level positions. We don't have a breakdown of representation numbers by line of business. What were the keys to improving advisor diversity, including adding more women, in the branches? The first thing we did was create something called the Advisor Development Program, where we hire and develop diverse advisors with no former financial services experience through a three-year training, development, and support program. The program started out in 2020. We now have almost 250 participants in the program, of which over 76% are diverse. The second thing we did was accelerate the number of bankers who get licensed and trained to become advisors, which is also a very diverse population and something that's unique to us. If you're a high-achieving banker and you've already got a partnership with the advisor, you know that branch ecosystem and operating model. The next step for you would be to apply to become an advisor. So that was actually a great source of talent for us as well. And as you probably read, we will double down on both of those things as well as increase our pipeline from HBCUs and try some other paths to get more people to consider a career as an advisor. I think if you go on campus and ask people, or if I ask my nephew's friends what they want to do, they'll say investment banking or they'll say consulting or they want to go work in a tech company. I haven't found one that said they wanted to be a financial advisor yet. The industry also has ground to make up with respect to female representation. In addition to the programs you just described, how are you trying to achieve that? We also have an internal training program for experienced advisors called the Advisor Growth Program, that's a two-to-three-year deep-training program around goals-based planning, where they come out with an internal certification as well as the WMCP (Wealth Management Certified Professional) designation, issued by the American College of Financial Services. We are making that available to our existing employees and we're encouraging diverse and female advisors to be in some of the earlier classes. You're one of the most prominent women on Wall Street. What's your advice for women about breaking through the industry's glass ceiling? At least in the business I'm in, women are running the place. So it doesn't feel like a glass ceiling. It felt a little different maybe 20 years ago but I honestly have never felt boxed out simply by being a woman. Work really, really hard, treat people well, surround yourself with amazing people who will tell you the truth, and you'll do well. And I'd say the same thing to men. I want to ask about your social media presence. On Twitter you've addressed some of the social problems and social movements the nation is experiencing nowâ€”gun violence, Black Lives Matter. As you know, a lot of people in the industry won't touch anything controversial or political in their posts. What are your thoughts about where to draw that line? I'm super clear, at least on my social media presence, that I speak for me. I do think people follow people, they don't follow brands as much. And I try my best to be my authentic, principled self. Where I try to be vocal about issues, I appreciate that there are other sides of it, but I think things like racial justice, racial equality, being against gun violence are things that most people agree with. Among those who work for you, how much latitude do you give to express personal views on social media? I'm OK with people authentically being themselves. I get that it gets tricky and that some issues may seem politicized whether they should be politicized or not. But I want principled people to work for me, and I understand that self-expression is part of being principled. Name a great piece of career advice you've received. If you want a bigger job, make your own job bigger. That's served me well in that I didn't always have respect for the boundaries of my job. I would just do stuff if somebody asked me to do it. Then people think of you as the person in the next job before you even get there. I tell people all the time, "Don't wait for somebody to come get you, own it." What's an actionable idea more advisors should be implementing? I think it's to ask clients, "What are the top things that matter most to you about your financial life?" and ask them not just about the financial goal, but what they want to do with that financial goal. Start getting more into not just growing the money, but what they'll do with the money, particularly now because I think what's important to people has changed. So even if a client said it's retirement or it's a second house, they may have completely reoriented that, having gone through what everybody has gone through. How do you relax and recharge? I have enjoyed giving myself permission to waste time during all of this. I didn't realize how tightly wound I was about how I spent my time, including the weekends. I was like, "I'm going to nap, then I'm going to work out, then I'm going to my son's game." And just letting myself go watch two dumb, old movies has been really liberating. Thanks, Kristin. Kristin Lemkau: J.P. Morgan's Plan to Scale Up Wealth Management

Speaking with Barron's Advisor from an office at a Chase bank branch near her home in Rye, N.Y., Lemkau explains how her revenue-focused marketing work prepared her to lead J.P. column5:
Inflation Fears Faded. JPMorgan's Jamie Dimon Betting Return.
Dimon, speaking at a Morgan Stanley conference Monday, said he expects to see higher rates and more inflation.
"Our balance sheet is positioned and will benefit from rising rates," Dimon said.
The Nasdaq, which hit an all-time high Monday, has recovered all of those losses, a sign that inflation concerns have dissipated.
*** Vaccinations Offer Protection Against Concerning Delta Variant Separate studies published Monday in the U.K. said two doses of Covid-19 vaccines by Pfizer/BioNTech and AstraZeneca offered considerable protection against severe illness and hospitalization from the more contagious Delta variant.
* On Monday, Novavax said its vaccine was 90.4% effective overall and 100% effective in protecting against moderate and severe illness in Phase 3 trials of nearly 30,000 adults in the U.S. and Mexico.
What's Next: Novavax's vaccine was also tested when more-infectious variants of the virus were on the rise in the U.S. Monday's news sets Novavax up to be a strong alternative to other vaccines and an agent for price competition in developed countries and the underserved regions of the world, such as India.
Cho *** Biden Calls NATO Alliance 'Rock-Solid and Unshakable' Ahead of Putin Meeting President Joe Biden accused Russia and China of trying to "drive a wedge" between North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations on Monday during his first NATO summit in Brussels as U.S. commander-in-chief.
* He said the U.S. considers Article 5, the collective defense pledge of the NATO treaty, "rock-solid and unshakable," calling it a "sacred commitment" to future challenges.
What's Next: Biden said of his Wednesday meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin that "I'm not looking for conflict with Russia," adding there are areas like cybersecurity where the two nations can cooperate "if he chooses." But if Putin decides not to cooperate, "then we will respond in kind," Biden said.
Cho *** Americans Are Keeping Their Cars Longer, But Buying More of Them The average age of a vehicle on American roads topped 12.1 years, a record, according to data released Monday by IHS Markit.
* The average new car price hit a record $38,255 in May, according to JD Power, up 12% from the same period a year ago.
North American new car production fell 3.4 million vehicles in the first three months of this year, said Cox Automotive, and expectations are for further cuts in the second quarter.
Cherney *** Boeing-Airbus Truce in Sight as Biden Meets EU Leaders A 17-year old dispute between Boeing and Airbus over government subsidies could be settled by a U.S.-EU agreement that may be announced after a meeting of President Biden and European Commission leaders Tuesday, according to several reports.
* U.S. Trade Rep. Katherine Tai and her EU counterpart Valdis Dombrovskis, a vice president of the European Commission, tried to clinch the final deal at their first face-to-face meeting Monday.
* A deal could take the form of a five-year suspension of the WTO-authorized tariffs imposed by each side on the other's products during the Trump presidency, giving the U.S. and Europe time to negotiate a treaty on subsidy limits.
column6: Many people think inflation is transitory. JPMorgan Chase Chief Jamie Dimon isn't so sure. Dimon, speaking at a Morgan Stanley conference Monday, said he expects to see higher rates and more inflation. To prepare, he's keeping a little extra cash on the balance sheet. About $500 billion. "Our balance sheet is positioned and will benefit from rising rates," Dimon said. It's not a popular call. A recent Bank of America survey found two-thirds of fund managers believe inflation is only transitoryâ€”just a function of higher commodity prices, which are destined to fall as global production returns to prepandemic norms. But a little inflation can go a long way. It could force interest rates to rise, pushing down bond prices, and it can also push down stock prices. Don't forget the February tech tantrum. A small rise in bond yields sent the Nasdaq Composite into correction territory, down almost 13% from prior highs. The Nasdaq, which hit an all-time high Monday, has recovered all of those losses, a sign that inflation concerns have dissipated. Yet just because the market has stopped worrying doesn't mean inflation won't be a problem. It might not be transitory if labor rates rise or if production has trouble ramping up to meet strong postpandemic demand. That's what Dimon is betting his balance sheet on. â€”Al Root *** The Biden administration is proposing some unprecedented changes to the tax code. Join Beverly Goodman, editorial director of investing & asset management, and Garrett Watson, senior policy analyst for the Tax Foundation, today at noon to learn about what you need to know about taxes now, and what you should be thinking about for the future. Sign up here. *** Vaccinations Offer Protection Against Concerning Delta Variant Separate studies published Monday in the U.K. said two doses of Covid-19 vaccines by Pfizer/BioNTech and AstraZeneca offered considerable protection against severe illness and hospitalization from the more contagious Delta variant. * Researchers in England found a double dose of Pfizer's vaccine cut the risk of hospitalization from Delta by 96%, and two doses of AstraZeneca's drug by 92%. In Scotland, researchers estimated the risk of hospitalization with Delta was reduced by around 70% after two doses of either. * On Monday, Novavax said its vaccine was 90.4% effective overall and 100% effective in protecting against moderate and severe illness in Phase 3 trials of nearly 30,000 adults in the U.S. and Mexico. * Novavax's success rate is nearly as high as Pfizer-BioNTech's 95% and Moderna's 94%, and better than Johnson & Johnson's 66%. * Restrictions are lifting in more places as U.S. public health officials race to meet a July 4 deadline to get 70% of the adult population partially vaccinated. Vermont dropped all restrictions after reaching 80%. California fully reopens its economy on Tuesday. What's Next: Novavax's vaccine was also tested when more-infectious variants of the virus were on the rise in the U.S. Monday's news sets Novavax up to be a strong alternative to other vaccines and an agent for price competition in developed countries and the underserved regions of the world, such as India. â€”Bill Alpert and Janet H. Cho *** Biden Calls NATO Alliance 'Rock-Solid and Unshakable' Ahead of Putin Meeting President Joe Biden accused Russia and China of trying to "drive a wedge" between North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations on Monday during his first NATO summit in Brussels as U.S. commander-in-chief. * He said the U.S. considers Article 5, the collective defense pledge of the NATO treaty, "rock-solid and unshakable," calling it a "sacred commitment" to future challenges. His comments contrasted with former President Donald Trump, who had threatened to withdraw the U.S. from the alliance. * NATO leaders on Monday condemned Russia for human rights abuses and election interference, calling on it to change its behavior. "Russia's aggressive actions constitute a threat to Euro-Atlantic security; terrorism in all its forms and manifestations remains a persistent threat to us all," they wrote. * Biden said that although the U.S. is withdrawing its troops from Afghanistan by Sept. 11, "our diplomatic, economic and humanitarian commitment for the Afghan people" and support for Afghan National Security Forces will continue, to prevent the country from becoming a haven for terrorists. * NATO's 79-paragraph communiquÃ© mentions China nearly a dozen times, saying its growing influence and international policies "can present challenges that we need to address together as an alliance." The 30-country alliance called for "a constructive dialogue with China where possible," on shared issues like climate change. What's Next: Biden said of his Wednesday meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin that "I'm not looking for conflict with Russia," adding there are areas like cybersecurity where the two nations can cooperate "if he chooses." But if Putin decides not to cooperate, "then we will respond in kind," Biden said. â€”Janet H. Cho *** Americans Are Keeping Their Cars Longer, But Buying More of Them The average age of a vehicle on American roads topped 12.1 years, a record, according to data released Monday by IHS Markit. Americans have been holding on to their cars longer steadily for the last 15 years, but the pandemic accelerated that trend. * The average new car price hit a record $38,255 in May, according to JD Power, up 12% from the same period a year ago. Retail used car prices are up 20% in the same period. * Two decades ago, a car would change hands once or twice and last 100,000 miles, The Wall Street Journal reported. Now, it's common for cars to have multiple owners and last for 200,000 miles. * Consumers have been adding to their number of household vehicles, IHS Markit said. The total number of vehicles in operation in the U.S. has risen about 10% since 2013, to around 279 million. * Auto makers are adding digital apps and convenience features to generate recurring revenue. Ford's CEO has said the company wants an always-on connection to customers rather than waiting for them to return to the dealership for a newer model car. What's Next: Auto factories are closed or operating at reduced capacity because of a continuing computer chip shortage. North American new car production fell 3.4 million vehicles in the first three months of this year, said Cox Automotive, and expectations are for further cuts in the second quarter. â€”Liz Moyer *** Microsoft, Ubisoft Show Off New Videogames at E3 Show The Electronic Entertainment Expo is back following last year's Covid-19 hiatus. The videogame event, better known as E3, is typically packed with surprise game announcements and presentations of coming releases. This year's virtual event is no different. * Microsoft showed off 30 games, 27 of which will appear in the subscription service Xbox Game Pass. Its newly acquired Bethesda studio will release its science fiction role-playing game Starfield exclusively on the Xbox platform and personal computers in 2022. * French videogame publishing giant Ubisoft Entertainment gave investors concrete launch dates and windows for several of its anticipated large franchises. Its showcase also included an action game based on the James Cameron Avatar franchise. * Take-Two Interactive Software, which owns powerhouse game publishers Rockstar Games and 2K Games, used its presentation Monday to host a panel on diversity and inclusion in the games industry. What's Next: Nintendo's presentation is the main event Tuesday. Though it is billed as a software showcase, the company plans to release an upgraded version of its Switch console this year, Bloomberg News reported, citing people familiar with the matter. â€”Connor Smith and Max A. Cherney *** Boeing-Airbus Truce in Sight as Biden Meets EU Leaders A 17-year old dispute between Boeing and Airbus over government subsidies could be settled by a U.S.-EU agreement that may be announced after a meeting of President Biden and European Commission leaders Tuesday, according to several reports. * European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said Tuesday that she was "very positive and convinced" a deal would be announced during the day. * U.S. Trade Rep. Katherine Tai and her EU counterpart Valdis Dombrovskis, a vice president of the European Commission, tried to clinch the final deal at their first face-to-face meeting Monday. * Brussels and Washington earlier this year suspended the various tariffs they had slapped on the other side's products after the World Trade Organization ruled in two separate decisions that both sides had granted illegal public subsidies to their aircraft maker. * A deal could take the form of a five-year suspension of the WTO-authorized tariffs imposed by each side on the other's products during the Trump presidency, giving the U.S. and Europe time to negotiate a treaty on subsidy limits. What's Next: An agreement would be a significant element of the reset Biden is seeking with the EU after four years of fractious trans-Atlantic relations. But in the longer term, trade issues are likely to remain a source of tension between the two sides, whoever sits in the White House. â€”Pierre BrianÃ§on *** Be sure to join this month's Barron's Daily virtual stock exchange challenge and show us your stuff. Each month, we'll start a new challenge and invite newsletter readersâ€”you!â€”to build a portfolio using virtual money and compete against the Barron's and MarketWatch community. Everyone will start with the same amount and can trade as often or as little as they choose. We'll track the leaders and, at the end of the challenge, the winner whose portfolio has the most value will be announced in The Barron's Daily newsletter. Are you ready to compete? Join the challenge and pick your stocks here. *** â€”Newsletter edited by Stacy Ozol, Mary Romano, Liz Moyer, Matt Bemer, Ben Levisohn Inflation Fears Have Faded. JPMorgan's Jamie Dimon Is Betting They'll Return.
